title: Texas GOP and UT - Austin leaders shift from championing free speech to policing protester intentions
message:
Greg Abbott signed a bill that enshrined new free speech protections on campuses.
And six months ago, during a celebration of Free Speech Week, University of Texas at Austin administrators touted the school’s expansive protections for free speech on campus — including speech that was anti-war or considered hate speech.
“Hate speech is not a category of speech the government can restrict,” Amanda Cochran-McCall, the university’s vice president for legal affairs, said at a school-affiliated Free Speech Week in October.
Free speech also loses First Amendment protections when it amounts to discriminatory harassment or true threats that incite imminent violence or destruction of public property.
Preventing unlawful assembly, as DPS described the governor’s instructions, is a slippery slope that can lead to preventing assembly altogether, free speech experts said.
event_breakdown:
- Texas, USA: Governor Greg Abbott signs a bill enshrining new free speech protections on campuses.
- University of Texas at Austin, Texas, USA: During a celebration of Free Speech Week, administrators tout the school's expansive protections for free speech on campus, including speech considered hate speech or anti-war.
- University of Texas at Austin, Texas, USA: Amanda Cochran-McCall, the university's vice president for legal affairs, states that hate speech is not a category of speech the government can restrict during a school-affiliated Free Speech Week in October.
- USA: Free speech loses First Amendment protections when it amounts to discriminatory harassment or true threats that incite imminent violence or destruction of public property.
- Texas, USA: The Department of Public Safety describes the governor's instructions to prevent unlawful assembly, raising concerns among free speech experts about the potential impact on preventing assembly altogether.

title: College students in Lehigh Valley react to Israel - Gaza events on campuses
message:
BETHLEHEM, Pa. - "As a Jewish student, I have not felt any discrimination or anything like that in any way.
I feel like everybody can kind of have their own opinion in that sense, which is really nice to have," said Lehigh University senior Max Colen.
Signs of Solidarity for Palestine are the multi-faith message from the Student Political Action Coalition at Lehigh University, which is holding a week of events, culminating with a rally Friday.
However, Colen's experience sits in stark contrast to fellow Jewish students freshman Aaron Besnoff and junior Jack Perkins.
As for some Jewish students, Colen may be relieved by what he's seen, but those like Besnoff and Perkins are only more on alert.

title: Hey , Hey ! Ho , Ho ! Campus Antisemitism Has Got to Go !
message:
A portion of the Columbia University lawn has become a tent city to protest—or more specifically, to protest the right of Israel, and Jews, to exist.
Patient Zero was Columbia University, but that virus has cascaded beyond the Upper West Side of New York City across the nation to schools such as Yale, Cornell, Cooper Union, and Tulane.
Columbia University in April is not like the University of Alaska at Fairbanks in January.
If a university president actually believes that there is a difference between that and what is going on now on their campuses, let him or her make that case.
Given the events on our nation’s campus over the past two weeks, it turns out that we were wrong.

- New York City Mayor Eric Adams claimed that the protests were co-opted by professional outside agitators
- Nationwide campus protests started at Columbia in response to Israel's offensive in Gaza after an attack by Hamas on southern Israel

title: Protesters take over Columbia building in escalation of anti - war demonstrations
message:
The police action happened on the 56th anniversary of a similar police action to quash an occupation of Hamilton Hall by students protesting racism and the Vietnam War.
Tuesday’s police action at Columbia comes exactly 56 years after officers swept into Hamilton Hall to arrest protesters occupying the building in 1968.
Israel and its supporters have branded the university protests as antisemitic, while Israel’s critics say it uses those allegations to silence opposition.
Occupying protesters have insisted they will remain in Hamilton Hall until the university agrees to three demands – divestment, financial transparency and amnesty.
AdvertisementThe Columbia University Chapter of the American Association of University Professors said faculty’s efforts to help defuse the situation have been repeatedly ignored by the university’s administration despite school statutes that require consultation.
event_breakdown:
- Police action at Columbia University on the 56th anniversary of a similar event at Hamilton Hall
- Protests at Columbia University labeled as antisemitic by Israel and its supporters
- Occupying protesters at Hamilton Hall demanding divestment, financial transparency, and amnesty
- Faculty efforts to defuse the situation ignored by the university's administration
